Below is a **practical cheat‑sheet** you can keep in the fridge or on your phone.  
It translates the scientific limits into everyday foods, portion sizes, and simple “swap‑in” ideas so you can apply the guidance without having to do the math each time you shop or cook.

## 1. Processed‑meat items that most guidelines flag

| Food (common name) | Typical serving size | Approx. amount of *processed‑meat* per serving | How it is usually produced (why it’s “processed”) |
|--------------------|----------------------|-----------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------|
| **Bacon (streak, back, or turkey)** | 2 slices (≈ 15 g) | 15 g (100 % processed) | Cured with salt + nitrite, often smoked |
| **Sausage – fresh (e.g., breakfast links, Italian “fresh” sausage)** | 1 large link (≈ 45 g) | 45 g | Ground meat mixed with salt, nitrite, spices; may be smoked |
| **Sausage – cooked/preserved (e.g., hot dogs, frankfurters, kielbasa, chorizo, salami, pepperoni)** | 1 hot‑dog (≈ 45 g) or 2 slices salami (≈ 30 g) | 45 g or 30 g | Cured, smoked, fermented; nitrite added |
| **Deli/“cold‑cut” meats (ham, turkey, roast‑beef, bologna, pastrami, mortadella)** | 2 slices (≈ 30 g) | 30 g | Salt‑cured, often with nitrite, sometimes smoked |
| **Canned meat (spam, corned‑beef, canned ham)** | 1 ½ oz can (≈ 43 g) | 43 g | Salt‑cured, sometimes smoked |
| **Pâté, liverwurst, terrines** | 1 tbsp (≈ 15 g) | 15 g | Salt‑cured, often contains nitrite |
| **Smoked fish (e.g., smoked salmon, kippered herring)** | 2 oz (≈ 55 g) | 55 g | Smoke‑cured → PAHs (technically “processed”) |
| **Pre‑marinated “ready‑to‑cook” steaks or kebabs** (often contain added nitrite for colour) | 1 piece (≈ 120 g) | 120 g (if nitrite listed) | May contain curing agents even though they look like “fresh” meat |

**Key tip:** The *only* feature you need to check on a label is **“contains sodium nitrite (or nitrate)”** or **“cured”**. If it’s there, count the whole item as *processed meat* for the purpose of the ≤ 50 g/day (≈ 1‑2 oz) limit.

---

## 2. How much processed meat is “too much”?

| Guideline | Numeric limit | What that looks like in a week |
|-----------|----------------|--------------------------------|
| **IARC (Group 1 carcinogen)** | No “safe” threshold, but risk rises linearly with intake. | **Epidemiologic “practical” ceiling:** ≤ 50 g /day (≈ 350 g / week) – roughly 2 – 3 standard slices of bacon, 1 ‑ 2 hot‑dogs, or 4 ‑ 5 slices of deli ham. |
| **World Cancer Research Fund / AICR** | **≤ 50 g processed meat per day** (≈ 350 g/week). | Same as above; many public‑health bodies adopt this as a *maximum* rather than a “goal”. |
| **U.S. Dietary Guidelines (2020‑2025)** | No numeric limit, but *“choose lean cuts and limit processed meats”* – most nutritionists interpret this as **≤ 1‑2 servings per week**. | Roughly 2‑3 slices of bacon or 1‑2 hot‑dogs per week. |

**Bottom line:** **If you keep processed‑meat intake to ≤ 1‑2 servings per week, you stay comfortably below the level at which large‑scale cohort studies have detected a measurable increase in colorectal‑cancer risk.
